intro: Astragalus runcinatus, commonly known as the hooked milkvetch, is a flowering plant native to the western United States and parts of Canada. It is a member of the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its compound leaves and yellow or pale yellow flowers. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky habitats and is adapted to arid conditions. It has small, pod-like fruits that contain several seeds, which are dispersed by wind. Astragalus runcinatus plays a role in stabilizing soil and supporting local insect populations.
